content: - start thunderbird on windows - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder - exit thunderbird - copy contents of the profile folder. - in ubuntu, click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird - now, paste contents of windows profile, overlaying contents of profile. - if there is a compatibilities.ini file, delete it - restart thunderbird
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks, that seems to have done it. I found a file named "compatibility.ini" and assumed that was it.

Initial startup of Thunderbird was significant -- 30-45 seconds? -- but in fact I've never measured that since it gets started up when I boot and I'm doing other things. I have too much old stored email.

Other instructions had told me to move up the directory tree two levels from the profile info, and to copy and paste that; somehow your instructions to just copy the given profile into the existing profile worked where the other did not.
creator: arghvark

content: Do you want to customize the order of your email accounts? Click on the AppMenu ≡ button in the upper right corner of th Thunderbird main window and choose Account Settings. In the left pane of Account Settings you can move accounts up and down with the mouse pointer to your convenience.

content: If the password was correct, it wouldn't be rejected. This may help: Verizon and AOL require an APP password when using email clients on a PC. I believe you must go to the AOL site and select the security page and can set up the APP password there. See this page for more info: https://help.aol.com/articles/Create-and-manage-app-password
creator: davidsk

content: What is the authentication method for the incoming and outgoing servers? It should be OAuth2, and the account password should be entered when the OAuth browser-like window asks for access.

creator: jblaurie

content:
1. Choose Tools -> Developer Tools > Error Console, paste the expression: 
  openDialog("chrome://pippki/content/resetpassword.xhtml")
  1. then, press the Evaluate button. That will open a dialog asking you if you want to reset your password. If Evaluate is not seen, press enter key.
  2. When prompted, press the Reset button.

This erases all account passwords.
creator: davidsk

content: If you do not know your email account password, you need to contact your email provider.

content: A guess would be your admin hasn't allowed OWL's client ID to have access to services.
creator: wsmwk

content:
Hey Paul,

can you please describe in more detail a) what account you have b) what exactly you did/tried and c) what the result was?

a) What is your actual domain name (part behind the @ in your email address)? Setup all depends on the domain. I'd need to check your real domain to see what's going on and reproduce the problem b) I assume you use the account creation dialog, not the new Account Hub? What do you enter in which field? (replace the part before @ with "foo@") Which account type do you choose? c) You first said "Authentication failed", then "OWL was not active" (what do you mean by that?), then "something about OWL". I am not sure what exactly happens. Can you please tell us what *exactly* happens?

Could you please make screenshots of *every* step?

That would help us understand, reproduce and diagnose and hopefully fix the problem for you.

Kind greetings,

Owl
creator: owl2

content: Godaddy may require what is called an "app password", "app-specific password", or "security password". It would be a new password, different from your account password, that could be used in only one app. I have my own domain too. My e-mail service provider requires an app-specific password. A quick Web search indicated that Godaddy may require them, but I did not look hard enough for authoritative information.

creator: paul710

content:
Paul Prince said
Yes, it was in a search I used someone said to do that. I turned off the new hub and added my account into TB. It created the account but I got an OWL error message that said something about my subscription. I forgot how much I initially paid for my OWL but it was unreasonable since I could get Office365 for not much more. OWL worked fine though.

You wrote that you added your account to Thunderbird. Is it really there or was the process aborted?

I asked about Account Hub because it seems that you turned Account Hub back on. We want it off.

In your place, I would:

  1. Disable or remove OWL.
  2. Disable the Account Hub.
  3. Delete my account if it really exists. (Do you need to back up anything first?)
  4. Try setting up the account again. Of course, use that app password.
  5. Stay cool, and report here.

By the way, do you know that Thunderbird supports only the mail function in EWS, not calendar or contacts yet?
creator: mozilla98

Btw, I got my BSc in Computer Science. In 1978. I am not dumb in tech but developers always assume the user already knows how to do things. My experience has always been users do not know the ins and outs.

Thanks again...Paul

content:
Hi Paul, Most of the Microsoft support that has been added to Thunderbird in recent months has focused on additional functionality within the Account Hub, so I think it's likely best to use that.

I also have a Godaddy Exchange Account with personal domain for tobypilling.com and have been able to log in and set up my account in Thunderbird using our Monthly Release 145 - using Oauth rather than the app password. Have you tried that approach?

We also have a preference in that version which allows more granular Oauth configurations to be specified, but I don't think that is necessary.

Please feel free to email me directly for any help with specific settings or continue the conversation here so other can learn from our "exchange".

Cheers
creator: tobypilling

content:
Dear Paul,

Rick wrote: > There are no developers on this forum.

FYI, I'm the maintainer and owner of Owl. I got involved, because your (Paul's) initial message sounded (to me and to others) like you had a problem with Owl.

Toby Pilling now also joined this thread. He's senior manager of Thunderbird desktop development, and competent - and kind as well.

Paul wrote: > OWL worked fine though.

I'm glad to hear that.

We worked hard and for years long to make Owl usable, and we regularly work on Owl, to adapt it to Office365 and Thunderbird.

Regarding the price: Owl costs less than 85 cents/month (cents), so that's hardly "unreasonable". However, I respect when you choose not to use Owl, for whatever reason.

Kind greetings,

Ben Bucksch Owl team
creator: owl2

content: I am no longer using v115 but it should work just as it does in v145. Some layout settings and open tabs are stored in the session.json file in the Thunderbird profile. Open the profile folder https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-do-i-find-my-profile then close Thunderbird, delete the session.json file from the profile folder and restart Thunderbird. A new session.json file will be created and hopefully work better than the old one.
creator: Mapenzi
